title: Custom Reporting for Acme
description: Acme's procurement team needs quarterly reports in XLSX format with their specific KPI layout.

outcomes.clear_success: Acme's buyer called it 'acceptable' in Slack, and the renewal is no longer actively at risk; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Reports generate, but they query 47 tables; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A competitor copied the UI and sales got two demo requests from Acme's competitors asking for the same thing; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Report generation takes three minutes and the CFO opened it once, then closed it; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: The XLSX export included six months of deleted user data and legal got a call from Acme's compliance officer; legal wants a meeting.

title: Demo Environment Isolation
description: Three enterprise prospects want to see 'clean' data—not their competitors' workflows in the shared demo.

outcomes.clear_success: All three prospects closed and sales sent a Venmo request as a joke; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Two prospects got sandboxes and entered trials; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A prospect demanded production-scale testing; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: One sandbox didn't sync custom fields — sales blamed engineering, engineering blamed the migration script; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A demo environment exposed PII from another customer's test account; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Salesforce Integration
description: TechCorp's entire workflow lives in Salesforce and they need real-time sync or they won't move.

outcomes.clear_success: TechCorp signed and the integration became the flagship reference; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Integration works but sync runs every 30 minutes instead of real time; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The integration is so tight that TechCorp's Salesforce admins joined your escalation chain; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Sync breaks every time TechCorp runs monthly data cleanup, and they're in trial — the relationship is tense; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: Salesforce API rate limits were exceeded mid-quarter; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: CSV Export for Apex
description: Apex Finance needs CSV export for their legacy reporting tool, which nobody has touched since the Obama administration.

outcomes.clear_success: CSV exports work and Apex is happy — now referenceable; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: CSV works but the column order doesn't match Apex's legacy system — they manually reordered and signed anyway; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Three other customers asked for CSV export immediately; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The export hangs on datasets over 50k rows; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: The CSV used raw timestamps and apex's legacy system could not parse them; update your resume.

title: Dedicated Success Portal
description: GlobalTech (800-seat enterprise) demands a private portal for onboarding assets, documentation, and training videos.

outcomes.clear_success: GlobalTech onboarding was 40% faster than previous cohorts; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Portal shipped and sixty percent of GlobalTech users found it; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: GlobalTech used the portal to document internal processes and now wants customization; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: The portal was built but never publicized internally at GlobalTech and the email landed in spam; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A support video went live with internal passwords visible; legal wants a meeting.

title: Custom SLA Monitoring
description: BigBank's legal team will only sign if we provide real-time SLA alerts and breach reporting.

outcomes.clear_success: BigBank signed a $1.2M three-year deal; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: SLA monitoring works, but alerts sometimes arrive five minutes late; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: BigBank's ops team now treats the dashboard as source of truth; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: The dashboard tracks uptime, not performance SLAs; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation bug showed you in breach for 18 hours when you were not; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: White-Glove Onboarding Flow
description: Citadel Fund needs a bespoke, guided setup with pre-filled configurations and handoff to a dedicated success manager.

outcomes.clear_success: Citadel went live in 10 days; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Onboarding took three weeks instead of 10 days; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Citadel wants the same treatment for a new team next quarter; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Pre-filled configs covered 70% of the use case; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: The assigned success manager left and citadel demanded someone who knew their setup; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Competitor Displacement Feature
description: Vertex has been using a competitor for two years and needs a migration tool that makes switching painless — or at least less painful than staying.

outcomes.clear_success: Vertex migrated cleanly at 99.8% accuracy; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Migration hit 98% accuracy; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The tool was so good Vertex used it to audit their own data and found inconsistencies; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Migration took twice as long as estimated and vertex went live with a reduced feature set until manual remapping finished; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A foreign key issue corrupted 15% of workflow history; update your resume.

title: Compliance Audit Export
description: Heritage Insurance needs SOC 2 audit trail exports in a specific format their auditors require.

outcomes.clear_success: Export tool built in three weeks and heritage's auditors approved it; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Export works but misses four event types and auditors accepted it with caveats; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The export uncovered 12 months of logging gaps; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: The export runs but the format is non-standard and auditors manually validated it anyway; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: The export included PII that should have been hashed and auditors flagged it, the board demanded remediation; legal wants a meeting.

title: Data Migration Toolkit
description: Three pending deals (each $250k+) are all requesting data migration from legacy systems.

outcomes.clear_success: All three deals signed; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Two deals closed using the tool; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The toolkit is now the bottleneck for enterprise onboarding; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: The tool works for 60% of sources; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A migration failed mid-process and left data inconsistent; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Priority Support Tier
description: Meridian Health is a 1000-seat account and they want 2-hour response SLA and a dedicated support contact.

outcomes.clear_success: Meridian's satisfaction jumped 35 points; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Response time hits two hours 80% of the time; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Meridian routes all questions through the dedicated contact, urgent or not — your support person is now a full-time Meridian resource; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Response time is reliably two hours, but the dedicated contact cannot escalate and meridian waits another two hours for actual resolution; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: Meridian hired away your dedicated contact and they now demand backpay for time spent on-site; update your resume.

title: Webhook Customization
description: Logistics Co needs custom webhook payloads and retry logic that doesn't exist in the product yet, and they're not subtle about it.

outcomes.clear_success: Custom webhooks shipped and Logistics Co integrated in a week; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Payloads are customizable but retry logic is limited to exponential backoff; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Two other customers immediately asked for custom webhooks; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Custom webhooks work 90% of the time; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A retry loop went infinite and hammered Logistics Co's endpoint for hours; legal wants a meeting.

title: Partnership API Access
description: DataFlow Partners wants raw API access to build their own integration layer on top of you.

outcomes.clear_success: DataFlow built an integration layer and you are now positioned as an enterprise platform; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: API access granted with rate limits and DataFlow can build, but throttling hits during peak hours; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: DataFlow became the only company customers call for advanced integrations; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: API docs were incomplete and DataFlow reverse-engineered half the API; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: DataFlow exposed your API spec in a public GitHub repo and competitors scraped it; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Renewal Automation Workflows
description: Synapse Corp wants automated renewal workflows so their procurement team stops losing track of contract dates in email threads.

outcomes.clear_success: Synapse's renewal automation runs flawlessly; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Automation works but approvals still need manual intervention and cycle time dropped 30%; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The automation is so effective their procurement team wants to use it for other vendors; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Automation works but does not integrate with their email system and routing is manual; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug auto-approved a renewal on the wrong date; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Account Hierarchy Modeling
description: Constellation Group operates 47 subsidiary companies and needs account hierarchy modeling that can handle the org chart from hell.

outcomes.clear_success: Account hierarchy works perfectly — Constellation signed and it became a product feature; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The hierarchy works for 95% of their use case; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Constellation's hierarchy is so complex that support tickets are four times longer than average; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The hierarchy UI is unintuitive and admins need weekly training; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A permission inheritance bug leaked one subsidiary's data to another — legal is involved, GDPR violations are being assessed; update your resume.

title: Territory Mapping Module
description: Regional distributors need to map customer territories and prevent overlapping assignments.

outcomes.clear_success: Territory mapping shipped and all three deals signed; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Territory mapping works but cannot handle complex overlaps and two deals signed; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Territory mapping became so useful customers used it for internal resource allocation; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Territory mapping works but requires heavy manual data entry and one customer abandoned it after a week; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bulk import overwrote the database instead of inserting and we rebuilt from backups; legal wants a meeting.

title: Champion Tracking System
description: Enterprise buyers want to track internal champions and stakeholders within their organization.

outcomes.clear_success: Champion tracking shipped and account managers use it religiously; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Champion tracking works for org structure but doesn't integrate with email or calendar — useful, but manual upkeep required; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customer success used champion tracking to identify at-risk relationships; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Champion tracking exists but adoption is low; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug exposed champion names and contact info in an API response that Google indexed; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Custom Billing Ledger
description: Zenith Financial Services needs a custom billing ledger that reconciles with their own accounting system.

outcomes.clear_success: The custom ledger integrates perfectly with Zenith's accounting system — reconciliation is clean every month and the deal is signed; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: The ledger works with minor reconciliation differences, usually under $500 a month; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Your billing system is now the source of truth for Zenith's revenue recognition; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: The ledger generates correct numbers but Zenith's finance team needs a weekly review call to explain the methodology; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation error overstated Zenith's usage by $200k; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: One-Page ROI Summary
description: Generate a one-page ROI summary PDF with customer metrics.

outcomes.clear_success: ROI summary shipped and sales uses it in every late-stage deal — cycles shortened measurably; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The PDF exists but needs manual edits — sales still uses it with a note saying 'numbers approximate'; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prospects forwarded the PDF to finance and finance asked for methodology; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The summary lives in the enablement folder and sales forgets it exists; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: The ROI template had the wrong baseline assumptions and a prospect caught it; update your resume.

title: Usage-Based Pricing Model
description: Move from seat-based to usage-based pricing to capture value from power users and finance projects 23% ARR uplift.

outcomes.clear_success: Usage-based pricing rolled out; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: The model went live and 12% of users upgraded; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Power users gamed the metrics and you redefined usage three times; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Usage-based pricing confused the market; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: An edge case made bills 5x higher for some customers; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Seat-Based Licensing Tiers
description: Introduce per-seat pricing with feature differentiation: Enterprise gets everything, Pro gets most things, Basic gets the idea.

outcomes.clear_success: Seat-based pricing shipped; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Seat-based pricing exists but most customers buy the one-size-fits-all Pro tier; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customers started rotating users between seats to avoid charges; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Seat-based pricing confused SMB customers; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A loophole let customers pay for five seats and give access to 50 shared accounts; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Premium Feature Gating
description: Gate advanced features (workflows, integrations, reporting) behind a Premium tier and see who blinks first.

outcomes.clear_success: Feature gates deployed and eighteen percent of free users upgraded; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Feature gating works with an 11% upgrade rate and $45k/month in revenue; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Free users found API workarounds to access gated features and you added API-level checks; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Feature gating reduced discovery and engagement dropped 20%; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A critical bug made all gated features free for eight hours and ten thousand users discovered them, upgrade rate collapsed to 2%; update your resume.

title: In-App Upsell Prompts
description: Show contextual upsell prompts when users hit free-tier limits — estimated 8-12% conversion if the timing doesn't make them hate us.

outcomes.clear_success: Upsell prompts deployed at 10% conversion on first interaction — revenue impact positive, users tolerate it, NPS barely moves; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Prompts are live with a 6% conversion rate; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prompts triggered mid-workflow and users abandoned; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Users skipped prompts 95% of the time; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: Prompts triggered in bulk for 50k users and looked like an outage; legal wants a meeting.

title: Annual Plan Discount Optimization
description: Test annual prepay discounts (5%, 10%, 15%, 20%) to drive upfront revenue and reduce churn.

outcomes.clear_success: A 15% discount lifted annual subscriptions 22%; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Annual plans worked — 12% upgraded, net revenue rose 8%; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Annual customers churned right at renewal because they'd been committed, not satisfied; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: The annual discount campaign had 3% uptake; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: Customers on a 20% annual discount hit product limits mid-year and demanded refunds; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Premium Support Tier
description: Offer dedicated support, Slack integration, and priority queuing for $500/month add-on and targeting mid-market.

outcomes.clear_success: Premium support tier launched with 14% adoption and $420k ARR; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Premium support exists with 8% adoption; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Premium users demanded escalation on non-critical issues and support SLAs became a liability instead of a feature; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Premium support reached 5% adoption; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A premium customer's Slack channel leaked sensitive conversation when a team member shared it publicly; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Add-On Marketplace
description: Launch a partner add-on marketplace (integrations, templates, extensions) and revenue share 30/70 split.

outcomes.clear_success: Marketplace launched with 12 partners and hit $60k MRR by month six; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Marketplace has five partners and $15k MRR; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: A partner built a competing product inside the marketplace and undermined direct sales; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Marketplace launched with no partners and revenue was $0 for four months; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A partner add-on had a security vulnerability that compromised customer data; update your resume.

title: Consumption Metering System
description: Build consumption metering to track 10+ dimensions (API calls, storage, compute minutes, etc.) so billing reflects actual usage.

outcomes.clear_success: Metering system deployed and enterprise customers can see consumption; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Metering works for 8 of 10 dimensions; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Transparent consumption made price-sensitive customers paranoid; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Metering is buggy and readings are off by 5-10%; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: Metering errors underbilled $500k over six months; legal wants a meeting.

title: Overage Charges Implementation
description: Add overage charges when users exceed plan limits (API calls, storage, users) and expects 8-12% of accounts will trigger overages.

outcomes.clear_success: Overages are live — 10% of accounts triggered them, adding $35k/month; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Overages are implemented — 6% of accounts triggered charges, adding $18k/month; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Customers sandbagged usage estimates during signup to avoid overages; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Overages triggered only 2% of the time; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A calculation bug charged one customer $47k for a single month; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Enterprise Pricing Restructure
description: Move enterprise from per-seat to consumption-based pricing with negotiated minimums — simpler for sales, scarier for customers.

outcomes.clear_success: Enterprise repricing completed; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Repricing is done; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Some customers interpreted repricing as betrayal; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Repricing negotiated but most customers negotiated better terms; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: Repricing went nuclear with two $1M+ accounts; update your resume.

title: Payment Method Expansion
description: Add wire transfers, ACH, invoice billing, and crypto payments so enterprise and international buyers stop bouncing at checkout.

outcomes.clear_success: All payment methods are live and enterprise close rate improved 22%; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Wire and ACH work; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Crypto payments attracted customers in unstable currencies; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Payment methods exist but adoption is minimal; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A wire transfer went to the wrong account and $250k disappeared; legal wants a meeting.

title: Dunning Flow Optimization
description: Improve failed payment recovery with smart retry logic, email campaigns, and alternative payment methods.

outcomes.clear_success: Dunning optimization is live — recovery rate hit 76% and churn dropped two points; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Dunning is live and recovery rate is 70%; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Dunning emails were too aggressive and some customers complained about the tone; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: The dunning flow barely moved the needle and recovery rate is 62%; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: A dunning email with the wrong customer name went to a large enterprise account; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Trial-to-Paid Conversion Optimization
description: Redesign the trial experience with better onboarding, feature highlights, and well-timed purchase prompts.

outcomes.clear_success: Trial redesign complete; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Trial conversion is 10.5%; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Prompts appeared too early and trial users skipped features; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: The redesign had minimal impact and conversion is 8.5%; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A trial variant extended duration indefinitely; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Pricing Page Redesign
description: Redesign pricing page for clarity, add comparison tables, calculators, and social proof and current pricing page conversion is 12%.

outcomes.clear_success: Pricing page redesigned; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: The page is cleaner and conversion is 13%; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Comparison tables made the product look more expensive than competitors and negotiation power decreased; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: The redesign did not move the needle and conversion is still 12%; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A pricing calculator bug showed prices 10x lower; update your resume.

title: Annual Plan Nudge
description: Add an in-app and email nudge to upgrade to annual billing with a small discount and low effort, should lift cash flow.

outcomes.clear_success: Annual upgrades jumped 18%; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Annual upgrades rose 7%; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users asked for refunds after forgetting they chose annual and support tickets spiked; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: The nudge blended into UI noise and conversion barely moved, but NPS dipped anyway because users noticed the pop-up; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A bug pre-selected annual billing at checkout — chargebacks flooded in and NPS cratered; legal wants a meeting.

title: AI-Powered Feature Suggestions
description: Build an ML model that suggests product features based on user behavior, competitor moves, and usage patterns.

outcomes.clear_success: AI suggestions shipped — engagement jumped 28% and feature discovery rose 35%; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: AI suggestions work and engagement is up 15%; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: The model suggested features that directly competed with your roadmap and users wanted them before strategy intended; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy was 64%; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model suggested a delete all data feature to 50k users; update your resume.

title: Real-Time Collaboration Layer
description: Add multi-user real-time collaboration (Figma-style cursors, live commenting, simultaneous editing) and find out if your architecture can handle it.

outcomes.clear_success: Real-time collaboration is live — team adoption jumped 75% and design agencies signed on; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: Collaboration works but has 1-2% sync issues; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Collaboration became the main use case and the original product became a side quest; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: Collaboration works but adoption is 35%; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: Websocket infrastructure could not handle 50k concurrent users; legal wants a meeting.

title: Predictive Analytics Engine
description: Build a predictive analytics engine that forecasts churn, revenue, and feature adoption — high upside, higher expectations.

outcomes.clear_success: Predictive engine deployed — churn predictions are 87% accurate and enterprises use it for planning; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: The engine works at 72% accuracy; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Predictions made customers paranoid about their own health; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy hit 58%, barely better than random; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model flagged 100 customers as high churn risk with 91% confidence — and it was right; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: White-Label Platform
description: Enable customers to white-label the entire platform and resell it under their own brand, because why have one product when you can have many.

outcomes.clear_success: White-label is live — eight partners are reselling and year-one ARR hit $2.5M; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: White-label works with three partners reselling and $400k ARR; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: One partner became a competitor and ate into direct sales; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: White-label shipped but only one partner was interested and revenue is minimal; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: A partner's brand infringement triggered a trademark dispute — legal fees exceeded channel revenue and the partner sued for IP ownership; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Ecosystem Marketplace
description: Build an extensible marketplace where partners build apps, integrations, and workflows on your platform.

outcomes.clear_success: Marketplace is live with 45 apps; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Marketplace exists with 15 apps and $200k ARR; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Quality control turned into a full-time job and low-quality apps tanked trust, so you built a review process; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Marketplace launched with five apps and developers aren't building more; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A marketplace app got hacked and exposed data for 10,000 users; update your resume.

title: Workflow Automation Builder
description: Add a no-code workflow builder (Zapier-style) that lets users automate repetitive tasks without code.

outcomes.clear_success: Workflow builder is live — 52% of users built at least one workflow, engagement rose 55%, and enterprise customers are locked in; someone writes "great job" in all-hands.
outcomes.partial_success: The builder works and 28% of users tried it; we declare victory and move on.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users built workflows that break when APIs change — workflow breakage is now 30% of the support queue; it wasn't in the deck, but sure.
outcomes.soft_failure: The UI is confusing and only 15% of users built workflows; a retro bullet absorbs the pain.
outcomes.catastrophe: A user built an infinite loop that burned $80k in compute before auto-kill; legal wants a meeting.

title: Natural Language Search
description: Replace keyword search with NLP-powered natural language search that understands intent — high upside, high risk of hallucinations.

outcomes.clear_success: Natural language search is live — satisfaction jumped 38%, users find things twice as fast, engagement up 22%; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: NL search works at 78% accuracy and satisfaction is up 15%; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Search latency increased 400ms per query; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy is 62%; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: NL search hallucinated results for 30% of queries; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Embedded BI Tool
description: Build embedded business intelligence directly in your product (dashboards, KPIs, data exploration).

outcomes.clear_success: Embedded BI is live — enterprises ditched external tools and dashboards became core product; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: BI works and 40% of enterprises use it as their primary dashboard; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users demanded drill-downs and custom SQL; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: BI exists but adoption is 15%; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: Large datasets crashed browsers — big-data customers couldn't use the feature and perf investigations ate six weeks; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: Mobile App Launch
description: Build native iOS and Android apps for mobile engagement — high impact, high maintenance, high risk of the App Store rejecting your first submission.

outcomes.clear_success: Apps are live on both stores — mobile users jumped 140% and field teams adopted immediately; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Apps are live and mobile usage is up 80%; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Mobile became the primary interface and desktop usage declined; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Apps launched but adoption is 40% of expected; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: iOS got rejected for compliance issues; update your resume.

title: Voice Interface Layer
description: Add voice command interface that lets users control product via voice (Alexa-style) and accessibility feature with enterprise appeal.

outcomes.clear_success: Voice interface shipped — 34% tried it, 18% use it regularly, and accessibility scores improved; the exec summary suddenly has room.
outcomes.partial_success: Voice works at 82% accuracy; the footnote does the heavy lifting.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Privacy concerns exploded and you added a kill-switch; the roadmap did not mention this part.
outcomes.soft_failure: Voice accuracy is 68%; the postmortem gets a new slide.
outcomes.catastrophe: Voice misheard 'delete archived items' as 'delete account' and wiped a customer's account; everyone pretends it was unforeseeable.

title: Customer Health Scoring AI
description: Build AI-powered health scoring for CSM teams (predicts churn, expansion, renewal risk).

outcomes.clear_success: Health scoring deployed to 80 CSM teams; leadership takes a victory lap.
outcomes.partial_success: Health scoring works at 76% accuracy; we call it progress.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: CSMs started gaming the score with 'health hygiene' instead of real adoption work; we pretend that was the plan.
outcomes.soft_failure: Accuracy is 64%; we blame 'execution risk'.
outcomes.catastrophe: The model showed bias against certain cohorts — startups got flagged as high-risk and CSMs neglected them; this becomes a quarterly lesson.

title: No-Code Integration Builder
description: Build visual integration builder (Zapier-style) that lets users connect to external systems without engineering.

outcomes.clear_success: No-code builder is live with 120+ integrations; it becomes a QBR 'win'.
outcomes.partial_success: Builder ships with 45 integrations; it still makes the slide deck.
outcomes.unexpected_impact: Users built integrations that broke your architecture and you added guard rails; nobody had that in the model.
outcomes.soft_failure: Builder covers only 20 integrations; it goes into the learning pile.
outcomes.catastrophe: A user built a runaway data sync that replicated endlessly and cost $120k in compute before auto-kill; update your resume.
